participant.affiliation: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Vice President
Chief Marketing Officer & Executive Vice President
Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President

plist.p: All participants thank you for standing by. The conference call is ready to begin. Welcome to the CN Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2012 Financial Results Conference Call. I would like to turn the meeting over to Mrs. Janet Drysdale, Vice President-Investor Relations. Ladies and gentlemen, Mrs. Drysdale.
Thank you, John. Good afternoon everyone and thank you for joining us. I'd like to remind you the comments already made regarding forward-looking statements.

With me today is Claude Mongeau, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Luc Jobin, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Keith Creel, our Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and J.J. Ruest our Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer.
The rules have not changed. In order to be fair to all participants, I would ask you to please limit yourself to one question. I will be available after the call for any follow up.
It's now my pleasure to turn the call over to CN's President and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Claude Mongeau.

Thank you, Janet, and thank you to all of you that join us on the call in the middle of the day. I know it's a big day for you, so we'll try to keep things moving and be as informative as we can on our fourth quarter results, which have been excellent. I think the CN team of railroader has turned in an impressive quarter capping a solid 2012 year. In fact, when you look at it, 2012 for us is really a record year, record in terms of volume, record in terms of earnings, record in terms of safety, so we have been able to finish the year strong and are very, very pleased with these results.

Revenues was up 8%, I am talking about constant currency. J.J. will give you some of the details, but the good news is we have the strong growth in certain sectors, but growth in all of our business units, so pretty balanced growth across the board is what drove this 8% revenue increase for the fourth quarter.

Our operating ratio was 63.6%, which is an improvement over last year and it's testament to our ability to accommodate that revenue growth at low incremental costs. And I'm particularly pleased with that because frankly this year, December was not an easy month, winter came in early in Canada and Keith and his team were able to maintain our strong performance metrics both on the operational efficiency side, but also on the service side importantly. And, Keith, will give you more detail in a minute.

In terms of bottom line, our diluted EPS was C$1.41, that's up 8% on an adjusted basis versus the fourth quarter last year, solid performance and the full-year cash flow topped C$1 billion just over C$1.6 billion for the full year and that's despite very significant pension contribution next year we took advantages from the cash that we generated from the monetization that Luc and his team were able to conclude in the early part of 2012. So, Luc, will give you more details on these results in a minute.

Let me just say a few words on 2012. I said earlier that it's – in many ways it's a record in the company's history. And I'm pleased that we achieved this record performance based on our strategic agenda. We have been able to outpace the economy with record volumes during the year. We really outperformed what the economy would have given us across the board really and accrued obviously the big area where we outpace the market. It's a new market for us. Intermodal, we grew much faster than our peers and much faster than what the economy would give us on the strength of market share gains, same story more market share against truck, but same story of gaining more inroads in the marketplace with merchandised products. So, all of these things adding up is why we significantly outpace the economy and we're able to drive record volumes in 2012 and we were able to bring that to the bottom line and deliver the record earnings as well.

Balancing operational and service excellence in our new supply chain agenda are what is driving those results. They are driving it at the top line, but they are also driving it to the bottom line, because frankly we are now getting to a point where our supply chain partnerships is helping us improve not only service, but also seek new ways to gain efficiency and that bodes well for the future because if you keep that paradigm going, our partners and us are working together to improve slot utilization, streamline cycle times in important bulk sectors, and to generally focus on better service outcome looking at end-to-end. And it's helping us as a result grow both the revenue and bring it to the bottom line.

So, clearly, we have a good agenda. We're pleased with how we finished the year in terms of driving shareholder value. In terms of our important constituents here, if you look at it, we are trading at an all-time high. Our premium is in line with the fact that our story is coming together and people have confidence that in the future. And I'll say a few words at the end to wrap up after Luc gives you the guidance, because I think we have solid potential and prospect going forward and we will not disappoint our shareholders and continue to drive shareholder value for many years to come.
With that I'll turn it over to you Keith.

Okay, thanks, Claude. It was indeed a great fourth quarter to close out a great year as you pointed out. In fact, these are the type of results that continue to provide compelling proof points that our agenda of operational and service excellence continues to gain momentum. So let's spend a couple of moments providing some color on our performance.

As you can see we deliver productivity gains across the board on a year-over-year basis. Each one of our key productivity measures improved, which I'm especially proud of considering 2012 business levels marks the highest volumes in the company's history. Again a powerful proof point that our operating team continues to execute a meaningful disciplined way handling this growth as a low incremental cost.

Turning specifically to Q4, as I said on a volume basis, fourth quarter was strong; in fact it was the second strongest quarter ever in the company's history. And faced with the heavy volumes, we produced significant gains in yard productivity, which is up 11% versus 2011. We realized gains across all three regions, but our shining star was Chicago where productivity actually improved 16% versus fourth quarter of 2011, which not surprisingly again our investments in Kirk Yard and EJ&E property continue to pay dividend.

We opened our renewed Kirk Yard during the fourth quarter allowing us to shift the major switching from Markham to Kirk, which is another step in our plans to consolidate switching activities in this critical Chicago hub. As you can see, we had incremental gains from trainload productivity as we continue to take advantage of our distributed power fleet to safely run larger, more efficient trains late on the foundation of our network.

There was a little bit of slippage in some of our velocity based metrics in the fourth quarter, that you'll see, that I've referred to those as moderate bumps in the road. We had some very meaningful operating challenges in the Western region, where we lost our mainline to Vancouver for five – almost six days in late November following a major rockslide. So making no excuses, but also we realized that winter does exist in Canada. It hit us a little bit early, especially compared to 2011, so against the backdrop a very favorable winter comparables in 2011. We did have some slippage, but regardless we've got a solid winter operating plan in place and we've already realized and produced improvements in those metrics. So, no concern, on a go-forward basis.

Shifting to a service focus that we continue to raise the bar on productivity, while at the same time driving meaningful service improvements for our customers and for our supply-chain partners; our focus on delivering our reliable end-to-end service is working. We strongly and firmly believe that by having shared metrics with our partners and meaningful fact-based dialogue and an understanding of the entire supply-chain, we will continue to improve the service that we provide to our customers while driving continued incremental productivity gains for CN and also for our customers and supply-chain partners.

In the virtue of that segment, a few key points to share, first, we continue to leverage our Car Management Excellence process to drive improvements in our car order fulfillment. 2012, we met 94% of the unconstrained demand for the CN fleet. This success was enabled by ensuring constant communication with our customers by having a good hand on their requirements and working with them continually to minimize any shortages, while we optimize our car movement. Second point, we continue to focus on the critical first-mile/last-mile of our service, which is what directly touches our customers day to day. Our customers know the window when they'll be switched. We measure our performance against that expectation. In 2012, as you can see, we achieved 91% switch window compliance.

Thirdly, one of the first supply-chain focus areas we tackled almost three years ago was grain, where we developed and implemented a scheduled grain plan. As opposed to centering success by hitting the right week with request to car supply for years ago, we're consistently providing cars on the scheduled day 82% of the time. This supply chain reliability has enabled a partnership that starts with the loading elevators in the prairies to the unloading elevators at the ports that have actually produced record grain limit levels for us during the fourth quarter. In fact, we set an all-time record for grain deliveries to the West Coast, loading and sustaining an unthinkable 5,000 cars per week spot program for an 8-week span, which in contrast to CN's history we had a record of two total weeks in our history where we loaded and shipped 5,000 cars and they were not simultaneous.

So in closing, I want to reemphasize the obvious, our strategy to drive operational excellence while driving service excellence is absolutely working both for CN, for our customers and our supply chain partners. We've got momentum on our side, the operating team and plan that's firing at all cylinders.
So with that, I'll turn it over to J.J. to highlight how our colleagues in the marketing department are converting this momentum into future growth opportunities.

Thank you, Keith, and good afternoon for all of you who are joining us today and special welcome to Janet for this quarterly roundtable. The next few minutes, I will review the last quarter, and then I will give you our commercial outlook going forward.

The revenue was up 7% from last year and the breakdown is as following. Same-store pricing on same-store sales came in just short of 4%. Volume was up 5%. Our length of haul was up 7%, carloads was up 3% and the revenue ton mile was up 8%. The revenue increase from fuel surcharge added another 1.5%. Then, the weak U.S. dollar conversion took out C$44 million or 2% and other items were slightly negative by less than 1%.

If you go on and join us on page 10, I will – you can read the result by business unit and this time around, I will only add colors on the more relevant variances and as usual, all my comments will be FX adjusted basis. I will start with crude. Crude was up C$50 million of incremental revenues during the quarter, an incremental 9,000 carload, but more relevant than just carload, we had very strong revenue ton mile coming from crude. CN is the long haul carrier among the class one railroad when it comes to crude.

Iron ore had a major drop of 15,000 carloads, but the revenue impact of iron ore was less than C$5 million in terms of reduction. Iron ore, in case of CN, is a very short haul business, in fact about 60 miles.

Next is steel pipe and the booming North American energy sector. We had our large diameter pipe, which are used in the construction of pipeline and our OCTG pipe, which are used for drilling produced an incremental C$12 million in the quarter that's a 50% growth for that sector. Domestic lumber and panel, which are driven by U.S. housing start, saw a revenue increase of 6%.

Next, the CN good and steady story on coal, our coal and pet coal business unit grew again this last quarter and the revenue was up 17% or C$25 million. U.S. grain and the Midwest drought, U.S. grain segment actually grew a solid C$28 million in revenue, mostly because of very strong export as the Mississippi River was a little weak. Fertilizer was up 27% or C$18 million. We handled more volume of fertilizer, and we especially handled more potash in the quarter.

And finally, the bright spot for many years to come, intermodal, overseas revenue was up C$24 million or 8%, domestic was up C$14 million or 8% as well. Highlights, the Port of Vancouver did very well for us last quarter. We had very good increase in the import from the CN shipping line. The domestic business was also strong and in that case the momentum was basically good across the board of all of the sub-segment. For the full year of 2012, the intermodal business reached C$2 million in revenue with an annual compounded growth of 12% since 2010.
Concluding on Q4, we produced C$200 million of exchange adjusted growth, almost 4% of same-store price increase and 8.2% of RTM growth.

Now turning to the commercial outlook and I will start with intermodal on page 11 and you will see on intermodal this year, the story is about new products, new terminal and new customers. Starting with organic growth new products, we are introducing new product such as returnable sled insert, a new service which is aimed to move long steel product in domestic containers to compete with long haul flat-bed truck. We also are going to be introducing this year cross-border reefer services for the reefer market, starting with domestic reefers for kind of U.S. movement, but also within – at the national reefers which we aim to bring from the West Coast port that CN serve.

To expand our intermodal's geographic reach further, we are adding new terminal. You saw the press release, we are opening in Indianapolis, we are opening in conjunction with a partner a new terminal. This terminal will open in June and it will offer CN direct service from both Rupert and Vancouver to serve the Indianapolis market. In Joliet, Illinois a new terminal will also be opened by the summer, also with direct service from both Vancouver and Rupert and this is a very large logistics spot market, has huge potential for CN. In Calgary, we just opened on January 10 our new terminal and we now have the capacity to expand our business in Southern Alberta for years to come.

Finally, we are also welcoming new customers in our portfolio. You'll remember that APL joined CN last October in the Port of Vancouver. MOL is now joining CN this month at the Port of Vancouver, and a large name U.S. retailer is opening store this spring and they will be joining us sometime this spring. So, all in all, we believe our intermodal franchise has the scope for another year of up to 10% revenue growth.

Looking at bulk, on page 12, our fertilizer volume will benefit from the restocking of inventory in North America as well as from our Canpotex contract. On the coal side, the Rupert export terminal just came back, in fact last weekend last week from an expansion shutdown. The new nameplate capacity of the terminal is now 18 million tons from the 13.5 million tons that it was. So therefore that's a significant, significant revenue opportunity for CN going forward.

The low water level of Mississippi river will continue to benefit our U.S. grain rail program to set the Gulf (16:37), at least in a short term. And on the Canadian side, you've heard Keith talk about our fantastic program of last fall, so his service will really keep us ahead on the export program in 2013 as well.

Manufacturing, I'm on page 13, starting with crude. What really drive the crude by rail is the spread in the crude selling price, the spread between Western Canada Select and the Brent Index, and we definitely have the scope to move – to more than double our revenue of last year. Whether you look at it in barrel revenue or carload, this could be a significant business for CN in 2013 and beyond.

Housing start will lift our domestic lumber, panel and intermodal revenue. And in fact some idle panel mill in our network should reopen later in the year, probably in the second half. The booming energy sector will drive many of our commodities, namely the large diameter pipe, the drilling pipe, the Alberta aggregate, the Wisconsin frac sand franchise, movement of condensate, all these businesses are a very good prospect for 2013.

On the negative side, paper, iron ore and steel products do have a weaker outlook. In conclusion, to wrap this up, we have a solid momentum in pricing which we will be maintaining this year and you should see CN as a disciplined growth story, a story that is leveraging our OR of 63, leveraging our leading supply chain service and reputation to marketplace and leveraging our bountiful and diverse energy franchise.
So on that, I will answer your question at the end and I will turn now to Luc.

Hi. Thanks very much, J.J. Starting on page 15 of the presentation, let me walk you through our key financial highlights for the quarterly performance. Revenues were up C$157 million or 7% at C$2.5 billion. J.J., Keith and their teams combined efforts to help us achieve a solid volume increase in most commodity sectors. And once again in the fourth quarter, we performed better in several categories than prevailing base market conditions.

Operating income was C$922 million, up 10% versus last year. This was driven by strong revenue growth handled at low incremental cost. Our operating ratio was 63.6% in the quarter which represents an improvement of 110 basis points versus last year. Other income was actually a C$5 million expense in the quarter compared with C$21 million of income in the fourth quarter of 2011. As we pointed out in previous earnings calls, this category is always difficult to forecast due to both timing and activity levels.

The category also combines income and expense items so it's really land and property disposals, income from passenger rail projects offset by expenses relating to real estate, foreign exchange, investment and other costs.

So in 2013, I would point out that I anticipate the activity level in this category to be significantly lower. As we expect both fewer land sales and passenger rail projects. On a full-year basis in 2013, I would expect other income to be more in the C$20 million range, in fact closer to our 2012 run rate for the second half.

Turning to our net income for the fourth quarter of 2012, it stood at C$610 million, up 3% and the reported diluted EPS was C$1.41, up 7%. Removing the impact of the income tax adjustment in 2011, the adjusted diluted EPS of C$1.41 in 2012 represents an 8% increase over last year's fourth quarter. On a constant currency basis, this is an increase of a full 11%.

As Keith pointed out, we came through with another solid quarter in terms of operational productivity and customer service. Yet, this performance did not come at the expense of overall cost management. The operating team continued to make progress in improving some of our key productivity and service metrics.

Turning to page 16, let's talk about operating expenses. Operating expenses were C$1,612 million, up 7% versus last year on a constant currency basis. At this point, I'll refer to the changes in constant currency. Labor and fringe benefit costs were C$463 million, a decrease of C$43 million or 8% lower than last year. This was a result of four elements. The first element is an increase in overall wage cost for approximately 5%. This was the product of wage inflation, up about 3% overtime was up 1%, and we also had an increase in head count by less than 1% in the quarter versus last year. Now GTM's were up 6%, so clearly, we enjoyed some 5% plus labor productivity gain in the quarter.

The second element is higher capital work during the quarter, which actually offset the increase in wage cost. The third element is the lower increase in stock-based compensation expense in this quarter versus last year accounting for 5 percentage points of the favorable variance. And this was obviously given a lower increase in our stock price through this quarter versus the same period last year. Finally, the last element relates to lower fringe benefit costs for about 3 percentage points and this was due in part to recognizing a benefit from terminating our former CEO's retirement benefit plan.

Turning to purchased services and material expense, it stood at C$340 million, up 17%. This was mostly a factor of higher volume and business activity levels. About half of the increase is due to more repairs and maintenance for cars and locomotives as well as higher expenses for contracted services and volume-related activities. The balance of the increase is really for other project work including information technology, business development, safety and engineering. The fuel expense stood at C$400 million, an increase of 8% versus last year. This higher volume represented 6 percentage points of the increase, while higher prices accounted for the balance.

Casualty and other costs was C$108 million, C$53 million higher than last year as we incurred higher legal claims, lower environmental credits versus last year, higher cost relating to workers' compensation as a result mostly of carrying out an actual evaluation in the quarter and generally higher audit cost. Our full year results for the C&O category were C$338 million of cost. We anticipated 2012 cost to be higher than last year and for 2013, I would expect a similar range of expenditures that is averaging approximately C$85 million per quarter.

Speaking of our full year results, they are summarized on page 17. We wrapped up 2012 with over C$9.9 billion in revenue, an increase of 10%. Our operating earnings grew 12% to reach C$3.6 billion, almost C$3.7 billion. The operating ratio stood at 62.9%, so below 63%, a 60 basis points improvement over last year. Net income was up 9% at C$2,680 million. This translated into a 13% increase in reported diluted EPS of C$6.12.
Excluding the impact of major asset sales in both years and some income tax adjustment in 2011, the adjusted diluted EPS for 2012 stood at C$5.61, a 16% increase over 2011's C$4.84.

Turning to free cash flow on page 18, this was another strong year. We generated C$1 billion in free cash flow. This compares to C$1.175 billion last year. This year's performance benefited from higher net income and lower income tax payments. This was offset by higher working capital for about C$425 million, mostly resulting from voluntary pension contributions that were done to the tune of C$700 million in 2012, partly offset by higher accounts payable.

Also, capital expenditures in 2012 stood at C$1.825 billion including capital leases. Meanwhile, our balance sheet remained strong with debt ratios and leverage within our guidelines. We continue to progress our stock buyback program of C$1.4 billion announced last October consistent with our strong shareholder return agenda. In that spirit, the board of directors has approved and we announced today a 15% increase in our quarterly cash dividend. Since the IPO in 1995, CN's dividend has increased every year, growing at a compound annual growth rate of 15% over those 17 years.

Finally, on page 19 allow me to address our 2013 financial outlook. We continue to see a gradual although modest improvement in the North American economy combined with opportunities in domestic energy related commodities as well as other export resource markets. We assume North American industrial production will increase by approximately 2% in 2013. On a brighter note, we do expect U.S. housing starts to continue their strong progression and be in the range of 950,000 units or so.

As for U.S. motor vehicle sales, we expect about 5% growth to approximately 15 million units in 2013. These and other key assumptions underpinning our outlook should translate into a 3% to 4% growth in carloads in 2013. As we've seen in 2012, we expect this carload performance to convert into stronger RTM growth from continued gains in length of haul.

On the pricing front, we maintain our inflation plus pricing policy. Having said this, our annual guidance has us aiming for high single-digit EPS growth in 2013 over the 2012 adjusted diluted EPS of C$5.61. Our objective is to achieve this despite accounting headwinds of approximately C$150 million that we see in 2013. These headwinds relate to increased pension expense and depreciation studies.

On the pension front, we finished the year with a further reduction of 70 basis points in the discount rate used to establish the pension obligation. This change in related assumption augments the accumulated auctorial losses, which must be amortized to the P&L annually. The result will be an increase of approximately C$120 million in our pension expense for 2013.

The balance of the headwind is our best estimate of about C$30 million in additional expense resulting from depreciation studies carried out periodically every couple of years to adjust the useful lives of certain assets in our balance sheet. Our guidance also calls for free cash flow in the range of C$800 million to C$900 million.

In 2013, income tax payments will revert back to a more normalized level of approximately C$850 million, given lower voluntary pension contribution. This means nevertheless a three-fold increase over 2012. So the 2013 cash tax rate will be much closer to our effective tax rate, which in turn is expected to be in the range of 28% to 29%.

Our free cash flow guidance assumes a capital investment program of about C$1.9 billion, and a 15% increase in dividends announced today. So the CN team remains committed to delivering superior results and creating value for shareholders as we continue to unfold our strategic agenda and leverage a solid pipeline of growth and productivity initiatives in 2013 and well beyond.
On this note, I'll turn it back over to you, Claude.

Okay. Thank you, Luc and team. As you can see or have just heard, we did deliver outstanding performance not just in the fourth quarter, but for the whole of 2012. We've had record volume with the 10% revenue growth. We've had record efficiency with our industry leading operating ratio below 63%. We've also had record safety performance and the rail industry are very safe mode of transportation and it's the key component of our service offering. So, when 23,000 railroaders deliver impressive performance like this, they want a – basically it shows that the game plan that we are following is gaining momentum. And it is this momentum that we believe will carry us through in to 2013. As Luc said, the economy is sluggish but it's constructive. We are determined to outpace base economic condition by leveraging our franchise diversity, our pipeline of strategic initiatives, and are continuously improving service level to drive our top line growth above economic condition. And, if we bring that to the bottom line despite the $150 million of expense headwind that Luc talked about, we are in a position to deliver EPS growth in the high-single digit and solid free cash flow for 2013. And, it's on that basis and with the confidence that I have, my team has and the board has that we've increased our dividends 15% again this year and are keen and committed to continue to drive solid shareholder value for many years to come.
With that, John, we will go to questions.
Thank you, sir. Thank you for your patience. First question is from Jason Seidl of Dahlman Rose. Please go ahead.

Thanks, guys. I wanted to circle on some of the growing intermodal business that you have as well as the expansion at Prince Rupert. Can you talk to us how that business can come on throughout 2013 and the impacts on RTM that you expect?

Thank you, Jason. The intermodal business at Rupert is really part of an overall game plan. Rupert, the terminal itself is expanding. There is a fourth vein coming up sometime this spring which will be installed. As Keith mentioned, we have also installed – expanded our long siding on the Rupert-Edmonton corridor, and we are anchoring that with new capacity in Joliet and Indiana, all this which will come out this summer. So, this is the whole effort to connect all these length to by and large to the US-Midwest import/export as well as take our place – fair place in Eastern Canada, Montreal, and Toronto and obviously this is long-haul business and it has a big impact on RTM. And from an RTM point of view, I think the mix up, I don't know if that helps, is that what you're looking for?

That helps a lot. I appreciate that. Guys, can you talk about as you expand this, are there any upfront costs in running additional trains or you guys are just going to increase your train lengths at Rupert?

I think we are, as we speak, we are running for the last several weeks now, Keith, correct me if I'm wrong, we have been to run two trains a day out of Prince Rupert everyday for basically – I mean, the last two to three weeks because there is very, very strong demand. So, these trains are running at train length capacity subject to weather and our siding capacity. So, we're already running long trains and we hope to run more of them in the future in line with business growth.
Okay. Gentlemen, thank you for the time, as always.
Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question is from Cherilyn Radbourne of TD Securities. Please go ahead.

Thanks very much. Good afternoon. I just wanted to ask a question on Ridley Terminals actually. It would seem that in a more subdued outlook for domestic coal and export outlook like that that's got expansion potential has become all the more strategically valuable. Could you just give us some kind of color on what length of time you think it may take to fill up the additional capacity that's just been completed up there?

Okay. Well, the terminal today, now has a capacity – to be tested this month of roughly 18 million tons. Some of that will be northern B.C. coal, so it's related to the production increase in those mines and its success in the marketplace. By and large, it's met coal, good quality met coal. Then you have some PRB coal, which is moving today to Rupert and I think there is a long-term future for PRB coal to Asia via the terminal that will exist. And then also, as you know, there is a major project in Alberta, the first coal project which is thermal coal, which is three years from now and that's a major mine that could be up to 10 million to 12 million ton. So, in fact, I think the people who run the Ridley Terminal have plan to going from 18 to 24 million ton because of the outlook they have on coal. Some of those commitment are through the reserve by people like First Coal who actually reserve capacity in the future to make sure that they have access to all. And so, there is a business case there for a strong coal business.
And what's the ultimate scale of that footprint from a tonnage perspective?
From 18 million tons, it's 24 million tons. From 24 million tons, there's also plans and space and land and water logs to get up to 40 million tons.
Okay.

The short term is to get to 18 million tons, mid-term is 24 million tons, and I think as J.J. said and he didn't meant – he did not mention Quintette for instance, a mine that (35:35) which is in the pipeline to reopen hopefully sometime in early 2014. So, there's clear visibility to fill that 18 million tons to eventually 24 million tons capacity, but the layout and all of the component including the road rail utility corridor that we are building as we speak, because I think they're about to break ground is lined up to eventually expand all the way to 40 million ton if there is demand for it.
Okay. Thank you. Hopefully, that was one question.
All right. Well, that's one-and-half and you've been always disciplined, Cherilyn.
Thank you. The next question is from Chris Wetherbee of Citi. Please go ahead.

Thanks. Good afternoon. Maybe a question just on the competitive dynamic within intermodal. You picked up the MOL business and I think J.J., you mentioned another retailer moving over. I just want to get a sense of kind of if there's been any material changes in the competitive dynamic between you and your counterpart in Canada? Or if it's more of a kind of service improvement in some of the terminals you've been opening up? Just want to kind of get a sense of maybe how that relates to the pricing side of intermodal going forward?

Thank you, Chris. I would say by and large, it's been organic growth. When you talk about new retailer, obviously it's business that doesn't exist today, it's new to any carrier. When you talk about new terminal that we're opening in the U.S. that's – we're really would not competing in that marketplace with our smaller carrier from the west because now when you're talking Indianapolis and Georgia, it's a different geographic area. So, it's coming from truck and for – in order to come from truck that's why we introduced these new product or it's coming from U.S. market, or it's coming from – in some cases there is somebody just going back and forth between the two of us and these are the two contracts that moves around.
Okay. That's great. Well, I'll keep to one. Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from Scott Group of Wolfe Trahan. Please go ahead.
Hey, thanks. Good afternoon, guys.
Hi, Scott.

So, once if you look on the head count side, so a good year of head count growth relative to volume and for sure relative to RTM growth. With the guidance for 2013 of 3% to 4% volume growth even better on the RTM side, how are you thinking about the need for people this year and head count growth relative to volumes in 2013?

Thanks, Scott. Well, first of all, we finished 2012 with roughly just a little bit under 2% growth in terms of head count and we finished the fourth quarter with less than 1%. So, we've done a lot of adjustments. I think we're enjoying good productivity. Next year, we're probably looking at just around 1% is what I guess what we have in mind at this point. Of course, we'll have to keep monitoring the volume and how it unfolds, but once again I think Keith and the team are looking to achieve some productivity growth, so we're going to try to contain it within 1%.
What's driving such a big differential that you feel like you can continue?

Well, what's driving it effectively is our ability to leverage our investments in our sidings, in our DP trains, longer trains, heavier trains, fewer train starts, fluidity in our corridor. Chicago is helping out tremendously, in and of itself the Chicago with the conversion into Kirk Yard. We realized synergies there from a head count standpoint on the operating side just from the jobs that we save from letting the multi-large facilities to the one which is a very efficient and becoming more efficient hub facility. One – something like that here and there across the board you sprinkle them out and all adds up and you're able to absorb several percentages of productivity versus what your revenue or your RTM growth is?
And Keith you think that's something you can keep – okay go ahead.

I think that you're pushing it a little bit with two. I want to keep Janet here. I want to have a smooth transition. When we had Bob before with the whip and we'd like to keep it streamlined, you can come at the end.
Okay. Fair enough. Thanks guys. I appreciate it.
Thank you. Scott.
Thank you, Scott.
Thank you. The next question is from Cameron Doerksen of National Bank Financial. Please go ahead.

Yeah, thank you. Just wanted to get a little more clarity around this crude by rail business. I think in the past you've talked about 30,000 carloads sort of run rate in 2012 going to 60,000 in 2013, is that still your expectation? And I guess related to that if I look at the incremental numbers you gave us for Q4, it looks like maybe the revenue per carload is sort of north of 5,000, is that accurate?

The revenue per car in the Q4 was quite significant. I think, one thing I've said, which I think you've – is a fact, is that is we do have the longest haul on average, so our rate per car is higher than maybe other railroads when it comes to crude. I mean, we'll go all the way to Mobile, we go all the way to Louisiana. You can all the way to both coasts. So we do have long haul. And often we start from Alberta as opposed to the Bakken. I mean, it has huge potential. The interest in the crude industry is for rail is huge, either because pipeline capacity is not quite done for them or they want to go to this to market, which provide a netback, that's physically the pipeline industry can't quite get them, so it's a question at this point of how fast we can move the different project and executions. We have enough. We're public about some of the project with, like Southern Pacific and others and the potential is real. We are sticking to the same forecast that we have offered and time will tell how some of these things actually come together, week-by-week, month-by-month.

There is clearly a huge opportunity. I mean, Canada is an energy power house, if you look at it, I mean we have gas, we have oil and if we play our cards right and develop the proper transportation solution, pipeline and rail to open up the export market and to open up the supply chains that provides good netbacks. There is a huge potential for transportation and infrastructure companies to help this booming oil and energy market for many many years to come.
Great. Thanks very much.
Thank you. The next question is from Tom Wadewitz from JPMorgan. Please go ahead.

Yeah. So wanted to get some of your thoughts, J.J., on the intermodal side, you mentioned a couple customer wins. I know it's a finite number of steamship customers. Do you have more – are there more contracts or customers, their contracts are expiring in 2013 that you would see opportunity for share gain? Or do you think these two, the MOL and APL, are kind of it for the moment and you have stability? And I guess to what extent you can have concern about you take too many away from the other guy; then you run the risk of a little more negative pricing dynamic? Thanks.

Your question Tom is quite specific, I won't go down that level of detail, but every year – I think every year all railroad – most railroad have major renewal, including in intermodal and that's just the way it is, that's how the marketplace works out. And we do compete with – in the Canadian marketplace with one specific railroad, and when our business get us cross border we compete with other railroads, other gateways, other port. And when you look at the domestic business, which is also a very significant part of our business, we are now into the different landscape, where in the Eastern U.S. we compete mostly with truck and another supply chain and the west it's mostly with our competitor for cargo. So, when you look at our intermodal franchise, and how we're going to be growing this year and the years to come, it will be like in the last two years. It will be from a range of different things not just CN, CP type things, whereas new location, new product, new supply chain, new destination. In the case of CN because we do go to three coasts, we want to exploit that, so that get us into market where we overlap with other folks.

I would say, Tom, just to echo what J.J. said, we sell service and we have a tremendous service advantage and we sell product innovation and we have a huge pipeline of new product innovation and we sell a beautiful franchise that's three coasts, and offers, I mean, I think an unparalleled ability to provide support and help our customers win in their end market and that's what we do and we try to bring it to the bottom line.
And we do.
Thank you, Tom.
Okay. All right, thanks.
Thank you. The next question is from Walter Spracklin, RBC Capital Markets. Please go ahead.

Thanks very much. Good afternoon everyone. Just wanted to come back to the volume growth guidance that you provided. Just when I was looking at the last – just roughly the last six months or so, noting that carload volumes versus RTM, there is a differential about 500 basis points here. And just curious whether you see that contracting in 2013 as we lap those or as we lap the longer haul business that you established in the back half of the year? Or is that a good metric to use in terms of forecasting our RTMs? And then I guess on a follow up to that just related though is, you went out of your way to kind of note that you had made some market share gains due to some service disruptions, I just want to understand whether you are factoring that into that 3% to 4% and say that we're likely to see that cede back or we're going to keep it regardless and we just wanted to highlight in the last press release?
Hi, Walter. I will just say you are trying to test Janet here with the one question.
You are not helping me, Walter.

Yeah. Let me say the following. I think the pattern between carload and the RTM growth you should expect it to be generally the same. Now, there is a lot of moving parts. Is it exactly the same from year-over-year, we'll see where the markets are and how they all come about. But the fact that we expect to grow our RTM faster than our carload, I think is a good step to back on, because the things that are growing are the long haul markets; intermodal, export potash, export coal, long haul, business in crude, et cetera, et cetera. So that was the best we can give you at this point in time. And it's our goal to position our sales where the markets are looking for our services. It so happens at the moment the markets that are hot are longer haul, but we're pursuing every opportunity where there is a profit to be made, whether it's a shorter haul traffic or a longer haul traffic.

And if I might add, we do have, on the flipside, some segment which are very, very short haul, which are already declining in 2013. Iron ore, year-over-year, we'll have less carload, but that's not a whole lot of revenue. We have a legacy contract on EJ&E, a plastic plant that's also will be going away. That's very short haul. That was from Chicago to Chicago. We also have the gasoline contract, that's also will be going away. They are converting the pipeline; that was also very short haul, Quebec City to Montreal. So, carload is kind of a tough measure to really have a sense of the CN volume. Thank you, Walter.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from Matt Troy, Susquehanna. Please go ahead.

Yeah, thank you. Obviously have a competitor who geared up to improve their operations in a competitive business dominated by two players; there is obviously risk of brain-drain or talent diversion or poaching. Claude and Keith, I will just be interested in your perspective, have you seen any increased turnover, have you seen inquiry, and how do you secure talent or what's your game plan should that that kind of poaching inquiry pickup as their plans get underway in the next two to three years?

As I've said before, we have a great agenda. We're gaining momentum. And there is nothing like having fun together, winning in the marketplace to keep a team together, when your stock price is high and the bonuses are paying, when your stock price is high and the long-term incentive compensation is paying, and when you are having fun driving an agenda that resonates with your customers and your employees, you have a winning recipe. And we have a winning recipe, it's been working for three years. And I think we have a winning team and I think we are having we're having fun together. And I don't see us losing people; if we do, we have a huge bench strength and we will carry forward, and continue to win in the marketplace.
Keith, do you have anything to add to that?
I think Claude summarized it pretty well.
All right. Thank you guys.
Thank you. The next question is from Brandon Oglenski of Barclays. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Good afternoon everyone. Maybe not to following that question, Luc, but something that we've had some trouble with is modeling the comp in (49:04) here. You've had a lot of volatility in the past two years and then you've gone from C$400 million in the quarter up to C$510 million. But looking forward, in the second half of 2012 you were running C$470 million to C$460 million, is that the type of run rate that we should be expecting with additional wage inflation, but some of the efficiencies that Keith was speaking to earlier?

Well, I think, again, you can see what we're looking at in terms of head count. So, I mean, we are anticipating wage inflation probably around 3%. We're looking at probably head count being up about 1 through the year. We did indicate that we've got C$120 million of headwind on the pension side. And when you're trying to factor all of this together, you should be mindful of some of the potential credits that we have discussed in the fourth quarter. So I mean that, I think at this point is the additional guidance I would give you.

And stock-based compensation, those will continue to be a headwind that we have to deal with, because it's volatile from quarter-to-quarter, but when you have strong shareholder returns and your stock price goes up, and given that our – a lot of our LTI, HCM is actually restricted stock units, we mark-to-market, so we carry the load with the benefit and pleasure of our shareholders.
Understood. But it sounds like maybe as similar outcome as the last couple of years as where you're getting inflation here but less than your overall revenue growth, is that fair?
That's what we're trying to do.
But I mean...
Subject to pension.

Yeah. And I'd be very careful because, again, I wouldn't personally use the run rate over the last couple of quarters. Those would tend to be low, I mean I think given what I have told you. And typically we run about 21% or thereabouts in terms of labor cost to revenue. So you got to be careful not to take necessarily the run rate, because there are a number of things that are changing. And hopefully, as Claude said, the stock-based compensation will continue to be a little bit of a headwind, so.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from Turan Quettawala of Scotiabank. Please go ahead.

Hello> Good afternoon. I just also had a quick question on the changes that are going on at CP right now. I know, Keith, you've spoken in the past about how this might benefit CN with coal production and so on and so forth. I'm wondering if you can give us a sense of whether you're seeing any timetable benefits flow through at this point in time, or maybe some color on timing on that or when do you expect to see that come through? Thanks.

Well, I'll give you one very compelling example, and that's what we're able to do with grain movement. I think you can see that both CP and CN through increased fluidity that both railways enjoyed that fluidity, enjoyed that better operating environment, that more disciplined operating environment, and I think that you'll see that it allowed us both to do some meaningful things for our customers in export grain at levels we otherwise never felt possible, so that's a very powerful proof point.
Anything else on that front or where else maybe you'll see some over the next year or so?

Well, I would expect it – I don't know if we'll see something to that quantum, but similar improvements in results anywhere we touch each other and interact and interchange cars. And case in point again, back to the holidays, CP has a much more disciplined approach to running their traffic as opposed to shutting down the railway which they used to do, which allows us both to realize car productivity savings and car velocity savings by not bunching up and congesting traffic lines.

As I said before, to have two strong teams competing hard for the business, to have two strong teams to emulate each other, and to have two railroads that are amongst the best in the world, is not a bad thing for shareholders and it's certainly not a bad thing for Canada.
That's great. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Our next question is from Ken Hoexter of Bank of America. Please go ahead.

Hey, good afternoon. Claude, can you just talk about the exposure to housing? Are you surprised given the strength you're seeing on the rebound here that you're not seeing more of a bouncing in forest products? And, I guess, leading that into your overall carload growth target of that 3% to 4%. What would get you to, I guess, be more excited on maybe even a fail (53:36) or what opportunities do you see for a faster growth?

I think we have some pretty strong expectations for growth. And if the economy is stronger, obviously, we will raise with that tide. But at this point in time, I think Luc gave you our assumption, 950,000 housing starts or thereabouts. I mean, we carry the vast majority of export lumber from Canada into the U.S. So, it is pretty direct link to our ability to grow if housing starts do increase to that level. In the last few years, we've been able to offset the tough conditions in the housing starts in the U.S. by growing with our customers' lumber exports to Asia. That market may take a little bit of a sideways and the U.S. goes up at the same time or if both markets were to go up at the same time, then perhaps there's upside, but we will ride the markets the way they come at us. And I think lumber into 2013 is an area that is very constructive, very positive for us.
Wonderful. Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question is from David Tyerman of Canaccord Genuity. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. My question is on the rail service review in Canada. I'm wondering if that has impacted your outlook materially yet and whether you have enough clarity right now to understand what the full impact could be and whether that could be material at some point in the future?

Yeah. As I said before, we really genuinely sincerely believe that supply chain collaboration and a commercial framework is the best way for CN and the rail industry to help its customer win in end markets. We've made that case. We are concerned about the impact of regulation in terms of unintended consequences. But having said this, there is no better recipe than improving service and delivering day in, day out to make sure that people stay on the mutual trust and commercial framework. And so we will be engaging the government as they come forward with the new law and we will be making sure that it's balanced and that hopefully it doesn't get used if they does pass the legislation by working hard every day at satisfying our customers.
So it sounds like it's not clear enough right now to state it in terms of impacts.
Yeah, we will make this a moot issue by providing good service every day.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from David Vernon of Bernstein. Please go ahead.

J.J., just a quick follow-up on the crude by rail volumes. You mentioned that the growth in demand that was really based on the spread between coastal and inland prices. And, I guess, I was just trying to figure out or get your opinion on at least, at what point, if that spread were to start coming in, at what point would that spread need to get to before you started getting worried about volume growth in that segment?

I think when you look – talk to the different crude producers, when you talk in the range of $8, $10, $12, the spread start to be tighter and rail is more expensive. It's a question of depending where you're going and how that works out, but rail is not the cheapest mode for the crude but it's a very good mode to get to a more profitable market, so $8 to $10. But we're a long way from that. And again, that's a general number because if your crude is high in sulfur and some of these other things which are tougher to refine, your spread is even higher than just that. So, it depends on the quality of the product. We talk about crude, but not all of crude is crude is crude, but some is better than others and it does have either a penalty or a premium in the marketplace.
And when you're talking bitumen, then rail is much more competitive with pipeline even on a cost basis, so.

Yeah. I mean, Claude is right, when you move Bakken crude, that you move it as it is. When you move bitumen, we don't move – we don't need the diluent. The diluent was not already with the product, meaning it's not coming out of the pipeline then we don't have to move the diluents, it's an extra saving. The people who produce crude, if they're really just crude producers, they're not integrated with refineries and they produce this heavy crude, the rail is a really, really compelling story for them.
Great. Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question is from Keith Schoonmaker of Morningstar. Please go ahead.

Yes, thanks. This question is probably for Keith Creel. Operations obviously are running particularly strong, continue to run best-in-class. Are there particular initiatives or CapEx projects about which you're most optimistic for improvements this year or is it more incremental little by little gains?

Yeah, I'd say it's more rifle-shot strategic, just a continuum of the story. We've got some more investments to make in Chicago that will allow us to take some incremental steps. Pretty excited about the investments we've made East of Edmonton in the Edmonton-to-Winnipeg corridor, which we'll start realizing benefits from. We put some additional signals in. We've got some plans to put some additional double track capacity in that lane, which will prove well for us as well and then we'll continue our BC corridor on the strength of the seven sidings we put in this past year, which increased our capacity by about 50% with year three or four of five-year plan to add some additional siding capacity up here. So nothing earth-shattering, but more of the same which will allow us to continue to pace with increased productivity on a year-over-year basis.
It's rifle-shot, but he has a big magazine.
Thanks.
Thank you. Our next question is from Steven Paget, FirstEnergy Capital. Please go ahead.
Good afternoon and thank you. You talked about loading pipe onto containers, in some way that would replace flatbed trucking. Could you please give more details on that?

Yeah. Basically we're talking 53-foot domestic container and it's basically an insert that looks like a flatbed truck, it's a platform. You load the steel, for example, a tubular tube, for example, that will go into Mexico to plants who makes parts for automotive, and need to be protected from the rain and snow and dust and what not, so they would be moving on the flat bed under a tarp. If you load that on that inserts or a cradle if you wish and then you slide it in a container and that's how the container product become a direct competitor to flat bed truck. And we actually have a video on that. I mean, Janet could probably link you to our website where we have a two-minute video, you can actually see the loading of the equipment.
Excellent. Thank you.

Quite exciting. Our focus on supply chain services, we innovate with new products. This is just one that J.J. had talked about, but we are looking to move finished vehicle and containers for instance in certain markets. We're looking to load plastic tank – flexitanks so that we can move liquid in containers. We've always moved bags and other such commodities, but selling – using the intermodal product to sell to different markets and selling one CN our key, key trust in our ability to continue to outpace base market and gain market share against them.

And have more than one source of growth and that always rely on just the one market or the one rivalry to be able to grow. So, a lot of focus on organic growth, where we can come up with a product that don't quite exist but – just I made an error earlier Cherilyn when I answered your question on coal, the coal mine in Canada I was referring to the – that might actually open for terminal coal is Coalspur, I think I said in the First Coal, I really meant Coalspur.
Thank you.
That concludes our Q&A, Mr. Mongeau. Please go ahead.

All right. Well, thank you. This was a good call. It's awfully cold there in Montreal and pretty cold across Canada. I know that because stop the railroad when it's cold, but we have momentum on our side. We're focused on coming through the winter with solid service records, and if the market demand continues to materialize the way we've seen the last couple of weeks, we should have a very solid first quarter to report when we next get you guys on the call at the end of the first quarter. So have a safe day and look forward to talk to you soon.
Thank you. The conference call has now ended. Please disconnect your lines at this time. We thank you for your participation.
